qas.question: In the 1990s, how many people were indicted for war crimes that were officially defined as genocide?
Convicted perpetrators Popovic and Beara were found guilty of genocide despite what evasive action?
Tolimir was found guilty of both genocide and what other charge?
Another charge beyond the act of genocide and for which Krstic and Nikolic were found guilty was what?
Three others were charged with participating in genocides in Bosnia by which country's courts?
In the 1990s, how many people were indicted for plea bargins?
What evasive action did not keep Tolmir from being found guilty?
What other charge besides genocide was Beara found guilty of?
What was another charge beyond the act for which Popovic was found guilty?
In which country's courts were three others charged with aiding and abbeting?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>About 30<b5_0/><a0_0/> people have been indicted for participating in genocide or complicity in genocide during the early 1990s in Bosnia. To date, after <a1_0><b6_0>several plea bargains<b6_0/><a1_0/> and some convictions that were successfully challenged on appeal two men, Vujadin Popović and Ljubiša Beara, have been found guilty of committing genocide, Zdravko Tolimir has been found guilty of committing genocide and <a2_0><b7_0>conspiracy to commit genocide<b7_0/><a2_0/>, and two others, Radislav Krstić and Drago Nikolić, have been found guilty of <a3_0><b8_0>aiding and abetting genocide<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Three others have been found guilty of participating in genocides in Bosnia by <a4_0><b9_0>German courts<b9_0/><a4_0/>, one of whom Nikola Jorgić lost an appeal against his conviction in the European Court of Human Rights. A further eight men, former members of the Bosnian Serb security forces were found guilty of genocide by the State Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina (See List of Bosnian genocide prosecutions).
